sen.j: 途中で西郷が被弾し、島津応吉久能邸門前にて別府の介錯で自決すると、跪いて西郷の自決を見届けた桐野らはさらに進撃し、岩崎口の一塁に籠もって交戦し、相次いで銃弾に斃れ、刺し違え、或は自刃した。
sen.e: After Saigo was hit and committed suicide by Beppu's kaishaku (assisting someone in committing hara-kiri by beheading him) in front of the mansion of Okichi Hisayoshi SHIMAZU, Kirino and so on who witnessed Saigo's suicide getting down on the knees marched further and fought based on a fort in Iwasakiguchi and they were shot down one by one or stabbed each other or fall on their sword.
sen.cmt: 「島津応吉久能」の読みが確認できておりません。
sen.e: After Saigo was hit and committed suicide by Beppu's kaishaku (assisting someone in committing hara-kiri by beheading him) in front of the mansion of Okichi Hisayoshi SHIMAZU, Kirino and so on who witnessed Saigo's suicide on his knees marched further and fought based on a fort in Iwasakiguchi and they were shot down one by one or stabbed each other or fell on their swords.

On the way there, Saigo was hit and committed suicide with the beheading assistance of Beppu in front of the residence of Okichi Hisayoshi SHIMAZU, which Kirino and others saw through on their knees, and then marching further, they occupied a fort in Iwasakiguchi and fought there, but they were shot down, stabbed or killed themselves one by one.
sen.cmt: 左記のとおり変更しました。

sen.j: このとき桐野は塁に籠もって勇戦し、額を打ち抜かれて戦死した。
sen.e: On this occasion, Kirino fought bravely staying in the fort and died in war being shot at this forehead.
On this occasion, Kirino fought bravely staying in the fort and died in war being shot in the forehead.

sen.j: 享年40。
sen.e: He died at the age of 40.
He died at the age of fourty.

sen.j: 桐野は明治10年（1877年）2月25日に「行在所達第四号」で官位を褫奪（ちだつ）され、死後、賊軍の将として遇されたが、大正5年（1916年）に正五位を追贈されて名誉回復した。
sen.e: Kirino was deprived of his official rank by Anzaisho Tatsu, dai 4 go (message of provisional palace for Gyoko (Emperor's outing) No. 4) on February 25, 1877 and, after his death, he was treated as a commander of the rebel army, but, in 1916, he was conferred Senior Fifth Rank posthumously and rehabilitated..

Kirino was deprived of his official rank by Anzaisho Tatsu, dai four go (message of provisional palace for Gyoko (Emperor's outing No. 4) on February 25, 1877 and, after his death, he was treated as a commander of the rebel army, but, in 1916, was conferred Senior Fifth Rank posthumously and rehabilitated..

Kirino was deprived of his official rank by the fourth notice of the temporary imperial abode (angusho tatsu) on February 25, 1877, and treated as a commander of the rebel army after his death, but in 1916 he was conferred the senior fifth rank posthumously and rehabilitated.
sen.cmt: 左記のとおり変更しました。

sen.j: 『西南記伝』四番大隊将士伝に桐野利秋を評して「利秋、天資英邁（えいまい）、気宇宏闊（こうかつ）、其人を待つや、憶を開き、胆を露はし、毫も畛域（しんいき）を設けず、然れども志気一発、眉を揚げ気を吐くに当たりては、その概、猛将勇卒と雖ども仰ぎ視ること能はざるものありしと云ふ」という。
sen.e: In "stories of commanders and soldiers of Yonban Daitai" in "Seinan Kiden," Toshiaki KIRINO was commented as "Toshiaki had excellent talent and open spirit and 其人を待つや,憶を開き,胆を露はし,毫も畛域(しんいき)を設けず, but when he is motivated and expresses his will, even variant generals or brave soldiers cannot compete."
sen.cmt: 「其人を待つや、憶を開き、胆を露はし、毫も畛域（しんいき）を設けず」の個所の意味が確認できておりません。
sen.e: In "stories of commanders and soldiers of Yonban Daitai" in "Seinan Kiden," Toshiaki KIRINO was commented as "Toshiaki had excellent talent and open spirit and 其人を待つや,憶を開き,胆を露はし,毫も畛域(しんいき)を設けず, but when he is motivated and expresses his will, even variant generals or brave soldiers cannot compete."

In the stories of commanders and soldiers of the fourth battalion of "The records of Seina War" (Seinan Kiden), Toshiaki KIRINO was commented as 'Toshiaki was an gifted and large-minded person. He was so hospitable and talked in a friendly manner and opened his heart to anyone without discrimination, but once he was enthusiastic and asserting his opinion, even variant generals or brave soldiers cannot compete.'
sen.cmt: 左記のとおり変更しました。

sen.j: 西郷隆盛は「彼をして学問の造詣あらしめば、到底吾人の及ぶ所に非ず」と評している。
sen.e: Takamori SAIGO commented on him as "If he would have been well-versed in scholarship, we could not compete with him."
Takamori SAIGO commented about him as "If he would have been well-versed in scholarship, we could not compete with him."
Takamori SAIGO commented about him as 'If he would have acquired an education, we could not compete with him.'
sen.cmt: 左記のとおり変更しました。

sen.j: 桐野は、慶応3年（1867年）の在京中のことを記した『桐野利秋日記』（旧称「京在日記」など日記3篇を含む）を残している。
sen.e: Kirino left "Kirino Toshiaki Nikki (diary of Toshiaki KIRINO)"(including three diaries such as "Kyozai Nikki (diary in Kyoto)"(previous name)) in which affairs during his stay in Kyoto in 1867.

Kirino wrote "Diary of Toshiaki KIRINO" (including three diaries such as 'Diary in Kyoto' [the former title]) in which affairs during his stay in Kyoto in 1867 were recorded.

sen.j: 今これを視ると、達筆とは言えないが、雄勁な筆運びで、勇武な気性がよくあらわれている。
sen.e: We cannot say that it is good handwriting but it is written with pithy brushwork showing his brave spirit.
We cannot say that it was good handwriting, but it is written with pithy brushwork showing his brave spirit.
We cannot say that he had good handwriting, but the pithy brushwork showed his brave spirit.

sen.j: 桐野は禄5石という貧窮の家で育ったが故に農民同様の生活を送り、系統的な学問をせず、剣術も小示現流の伊集院鴨居門下あるいは薬丸自顕流の薬丸兼義（江夏仲左衛門とも）門下というが、多くは独力で修得し、達人の域に至った。
sen.e: Because he was brought up in poor family with roku (stipend) 5 koku 902 liters, approx.), he lived same as a farmer and could not learn systematically and, with respect to kenj;utsu (swordplay), although it is said that he learned from Kamoi IJUIN of Kojigenryu or Kaneyoshi YAKUMARU (or Chuzaemon ENATSU) of Yakumaru Jigenryu, he learned mainly by himself and reached the level of master.

Because he was brought up in a poor family with roku (stipend) five koku 902 liters, approx.), he lived the same as a farmer and could not learn systematically and, with respect to kenj;utsu (swordplay), although it is said that he learned from Kamoi IJUIN of Kojigenryu or Kaneyoshi YAKUMARU (or Chuzaemon ENATSU) of Yakumaru Jigenryu, he learned mainly by himself and reached the level of master.

Because he was brought up in a poor samurai family with a stipend of only five koku and lived the same as a farmer, he could not study systematically, and although he was said to learn swordplay from Kamoi IJUIN of the Kojigenryu school or Kaneyoshi YAKUMARU (or Chuzaemon ENATSU) of the Yakumaru-jigenryu school, he learned it almost by himself and reached the level of master.
sen.cmt: 左記のとおり変更しました。

sen.j: 無学文盲というのは誤りである。
sen.e: It is wrong to say that he was ignorant and illiterate.
It is wrong to say that he was ignorant and illiterate.
It is wrong to say that he was ignorant and illiterate.

sen.j: 日記中の記述（上手とは言えないが、和歌さえつくっている）を見る限り、読み書きに充分な教養があったことは確かである（読み書きは主に外祖父別府四郎兵衛から教わった）。
sen.e: As far as we judge on descriptions in the diaries (he even made waka, although we cannot say it is a good one), it is sure that he was learned sufficient for reading and writing.. (He learned reading and writing from his maternal grandfather Shirobei BEPPU.)

As far as we can judge on descriptions in the diaries (he even created waka, although we cannot say it was a good one), it is sure that he was learned sufficiently for reading and writing.. (He learned reading and writing from his maternal grandfather Shirobei BEPPU.)

As far as we can judge on descriptions in the diaries (he even created waka poems, although we cannot say they were good), he was certain to have enough education for reading and writing, (and he learned reading and writing from his maternal grandfather, Shirobei BEPPU).
sen.cmt: 左記のとおり変更しました。

sen.j: ただ当時の武士の教養であった漢文を正確に読み書きできず、話中の漢語が理解できなかったから、彼らから嫉みも込めて無学と呼ばれたと思われる。
sen.e: As he could not read and write classical Chinese, which was culture for samurai at that time, correctly and could not understand Chinese words in conversation, it is inferred that he was criticized as ignorant partly because of jealousy.

As he could not read and write classical Chinese, which was culture for samurai at that time, correctly and could not understand Chinese words in conversation, it is inferred that he was criticized as ignorant partly because of jealousy.

It seemed that he was called an ignorant in jealous contempt because he could not read or write classical Chinese correctly, nor understand Chinese words in conversation, which was a general education for the samurai class at that time.
sen.cmt: 左記のとおり変更しました。

sen.j: 西郷の評語が「学問あらしめば」ではなく、「学問の造詣あらしめば」となっていることを吟味すべきであろう（この場合の学問は四書五経を意味している。）
sen.e: It should be considered that Saigo's comment was not "If he had scholarship" but "well-versed in scholorship." (In this case, "scholarship" means shishogokyo (the Four Books and Five Classics of Confucianism, the Nine Chinese Classics).

It should be considered that Saigo's comment was not "If he had scholarship" but "well-versed in scholorship." (In this case, "scholarship" means shishogokyo (the Four Books and Five Classics of Confucianism, the Nine Chinese Classics).

It should be noted that Saigo's comment was not 'if he had a talent for education' but 'if he would have acquired an education,' (and in this case 'education' means the learning of the Nine Chinese Classics).
sen.cmt: 左記のとおり変更しました。

sen.j: 市来四郎の『丁丑擾乱記』には、「世人、これ（桐野）を武断の人というといえども、その深きを知らざるなり。六年の冬掛冠帰省の後は、居常国事の救うべからざるを憂嘆し、皇威不墜の策を講じ、国民をして文明の域に立たしめんことを主張し、速に立憲の政体に改革し、民権を拡張せんことを希望する最も切なり」とある。
sen.e: "Teigo Joranki" by Shiro ICHIKI describes as "Although people say that he (Kirino) was a militarist, but it is because they do not know his deepness. After he resigned and returned to home in the winter of 1873, he was afraid that affairs of the state cannot be corrected, and insisted to take measures to prevent degradation of authority of the emperor and enlighten citizens and he wished to improve to a constitutional state and expand people's right."
sen.cmt: 「丁丑擾乱記」の読みが確認できておりません。
sen.e: "Teigo Joranki" by Shiro ICHIKI describes; "Although people say he (Kirino) was a militarist, it is because they do not know his depth. After he resigned and returned home in the winter of 1873, he was afraid that the affairs of state could not be corrected, and insisted taking measures to prevent the degradation of authority of the emperor and enlighten citizens and he wished to improve the constitutional state and expand people's rights."

In "The Record of the Disturbance in 1877" (Teichu Joranki) by Shiro ICHIKI he was described as 'Although people say he (Kirino) was a militarist, they do not know his profound idea. After he resigned and returned home in the winter of 1873, he always worried that the affairs of state could not be corrected, thought up measures to prevent the degradation of the imperial authority and insisted that it was necessary to enlighten the people. And most of all, he wished to establish the constitutional state and expand people's rights.'
sen.cmt: 左記のとおり変更しました。

sen.j: また同書には、「桐野は廉潔剛胆百折不撓の人というべし。最も慈悲心あり。文識はなはだ乏し。自ら文盲を唱う。しかりといえども実務上すこぶる思慮深遠、有識者に勝れり」ともある。
sen.e: He had bowels of mercy. Kirino should be called a man of integrity, nerves of steel, toughness and adamancy. His knowledge on books was poor. He called himself illiterate. However, he was vary capable with practical matters and superior to learned persons.

He had bowels of mercy. Kirino should be called a man of integrity, nerves of steel, toughness and adamancy. His knowledge on books was poor. He called himself illiterate. However, he was vary capable with practical matters and superior to learned persons.

There was another description, reading as 'Kirino should be called a man of integrity, valiant and fearless with an unyielding spirit. He is the most merciful, but poorly educated and called himself an illiterate. But once he is in duty, he becomes an able commander with prudence, even superior to the learned person.'
sen.cmt: 左記のとおり変更しました。

sen.j: 会津戦争での会津若松城受け取りの時、堂々とした態度で軍監としての作法を勤めた。

sen.j: 後に「あのような作法をどこで学んだのか」と訪ねられたとき、「愛宕の小屋で忠臣蔵の芝居を見て、赤穂城明け渡しの部分をそっくり真似ただけだ」と答えたという逸話が残っている。

sen.j: 後年、勝海舟は「（西郷の）部下にも、桐野とか村田とかいうのは、なかなか俊才であった」（『氷川清話』）、大隈重信は「西南の役に大西郷に次いでの薩摩の驍将桐野利秋、彼はすこぶる才幹の男であったが、これがやはり派手であった。身体も大きくて立派なら容貌態度ともに優れた男であったが、着物をぶざまに着るようなまねはせず、それも汚れ目の見えぬきれいな物づくめであった」（『早稲田清話』）と評している。
